Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandfather for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I was waiting at the taxi stand, engine idling, when my phone buzzed. It was my grandson, his message urgent: “Grandpa, can I call you? I really need your advice.” My heart tightened. He never reached out like this unless it was serious. I wanted to be there for him, to listen and offer the guidance he trusted me for. Just then, two travelers approached, dragging heavy suitcases. “Can you help us load these? We’re in a hurry, and we’ll split the fare,” one said, glancing at his watch. As a taxi driver, I knew I had to be professional—help them quickly, get them to their destination, keep the meter running. But my mind was with my grandson, picturing him waiting for my call, needing me not as a driver, but as his grandfather. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
